content: Care to share what you concluded? It's always more satisfying to hear what people have learned in the end!

Yeah, Morgan, I totally forgot that there are two things called the bar construction. One is used for computing nice resolutions of objects or fibrant/cofibrant replacement. and the other one is used to give a kind of "delooping". Of course they are very closely related but they seem to have pretty different properties, as far as I can tell

I was reading the words "bar construction" in the textbook and thinking of the version of the bar construction where you have some monad or comonad and you iterate it repeatedly to give rise to a kind of simplicial or cosimplicial resolution of the object. The bar construction in this book i think is an example of the more general version given here
https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/two-sided+bar+construction

You want to think of the unit 111 as both a left and right module of VVV and carry out the construction of B(1,V,1)B(1,V,1)B(1,V,1), and that'll give you this complex after taking the Moore normalization.
Actually I have a new question now.

My question is: Intuitively, if VVV is an augmented algebra, why should BVBVBV be a coalgebra? The comultiplication map is fairly simple and straightforward but why would you expect it to be an interesting aspect, or why a priori would you think that BVBVBV would be a coalgebra because of what it represents

Patrick Nicodemus said:

For a while I have been studying a construction involving the Day convolution of presheaves, which can be understood as a Kan extension, and recently I tried to dualize it to get a similar construction for the right adjoint internal hom functor, but I had a lot of difficulty because of the mixed variance of Hom, contravariant in one variable and covariant in another. Some constructions I wanted to carry out were clearly not functorial.
However, I realized how to solve my problem! The issues with covariance and contravariance can be solved by passing from the 2-category of categories to the bicategory of profunctors. There, I was able to prove that I can give the analogous construction for Hom as a right Kan extension in the category of profunctors :big_smile:

(This is closely related to the cobar construction, which i have been struggling to interpret categorically)

I am studying the book on Algebraic Operads by Loday and Vallette and it treats everything in terms of chain complexes. Theoretically, by Dold-Kan, everything we say about chain complexes could be said in terms of simplicial vector spaces and vice versa, it is just a matter of computational convenience and translation. Can anyone recommend any books or papers where some of the same basic subject matter is treated in the category of simplicial vector spaces - for example, twisting morphisms, bar/cobar duality, etc, all treated without converting everything to chain complexes? I have not found such papers.
I have been trying to translate it myself to get a better understanding for the constructions but it is tedious and there is lots of possibility for error
I don't know any such references, but would be interested to hear an answer to this too!

You might want to look into the derived algebraic geometry literature. There they study derived schemes, which are like schemes, only not glued together from rings (i.e. commutative monoids in abelian groups with ⊗\otimes⊗) but from E∞E_\inftyE∞​-algebras in simplicial abelian groups or in simplicial abelian k-algebras. In characteristic 000 one can replace simplicial abelian groups by chain complexes, but not in characteristic >0.
If it is readable to you, you might also look at Lurie's Higher Algebra from Prop. 7.1.4.11 onwards.

Suppose we have an adjunction F:C→DF: C\to DF:C→D, U:D→CU : D\to CU:D→C with FFF left adjoint to UUU. Write G=FUG=FUG=FU for the comonad arising from the adjunction. If we use η:idC→UF\eta : \mathbf{id}_C \to UFη:idC​→UF and ε:FU→idD \varepsilon : FU \to \mathbf{id}_Dε:FU→idD​ for the unit and counit arising from the multiplication, then write δ\deltaδ for the comultiplication FηUF\eta UFηU of GGG.

If XXX is an object in DDD, then the bar construction allows us to "resolve" XXX by a simplicial object whose objects are all "free". The meaning of free here is up for debate, but we could take as the definition of "free" to mean: lying in the image of FFF, lying in the image of GGG, etc. I prefer to take as the definition of free, "is a GGG coalgebra" as this is weak enough that it subsumes the other two cases but strong enough that we can derive interesting properties of free objects, for example a projective lifting property.

Thus I am tempted to say: The bar construction resolves an object in DDD by a simplicial object composed of GGG coalgebras. However, this is not a simplicial GGG coalgebra, as the first face map d0:GGX→GXd_0 : GGX \to GXd0​:GGX→GX is εG\varepsilon_GεG​, which is not a coalgebra map (where GGXGGXGGX and GXGXGX carry the expected free coalgebra structure.)

Therefore we have a simplicial object where all objects are GGG coalgebras and all face and degeneracy maps are GGG coalgebras, _except_ d0d_0d0​. It is a bit of an awkward exception!

I am wondering if anyone can tell me if such objects are studied in the literature, or more generally, are there interesting properties of simplicial sets which require that all face and degeneracy maps except for d0d_0d0​ satisfy a given property. I have come across some elsewhere, but I don't know if it is connected.

My mind is not focused on this stuff now, but I think what nature is telling you is that it's wrong to think of a resolution the way you're doing. E.g. in the case of abelian groups, don't think of a resolution of AAA as a chain complex

⋯→A2→A1→A0→A \cdots \to A_2 \to A_1 \to A_0 \to A ⋯→A2​→A1​→A0​→A

Think of it as a chain complex

⋯A2→A1→A0 \cdots A_2 \to A_1 \to A_0 ⋯A2​→A1​→A0​

which is equipped with a map of chain complexes to

⋯0→0→A \cdots 0 \to 0 \to A ⋯0→0→A

This map is a quasi-isomorphism, and it's a cofibration, so its exhibiting

⋯A2→A1→A0 \cdots A_2 \to A_1 \to A_0 ⋯A2​→A1​→A0​

as a cofibrant replacement of the original AAA. This was the philosophy I was espousing earlier.

The same idea should also work in the more explicitly simplicial framework.

Patrick Nicodemus said:

If XXX is an object in DDD, then the bar construction allows us to "resolve" XXX by a simplicial object whose objects are all "free". The meaning of free here is up for debate, but we could take as the definition of "free" to mean: lying in the image of FFF, lying in the image of GGG, etc. I prefer...

Yeah, I don't think "free" should mean "lies in the image of FFF" or "lies in the image of GGG" - those are properties of an object, but I think freedom should be a structure.

For example, you can try to define a "free group" to be a group HHH with the property that there exists some set XXX such that HHH is isomorphic to the free group on XXX, but I think this is less useful, in general, than the concept of a group being "free on the set XXX", which is a structure on a group, involving a universal property and a specific set XXX.

Btw @Patrick Nicodemus, if you read my tweet about "decalage" you'll see now that I've replaced it by something better about how to think of a free resolution as a simplicial object, namely not having the original object AAA as the object of 0-simplices, but the free object A0A_0A0​.

If you want to understand this stuff really thoroughly I recommend this:

  • Todd Trimble, Bar constructions.

The punchline is the main theorem. It's stated in huge generality, but the basic idea is that starting with an algebra X of a monad M, the bar construction produces a simplicial algebra of that monad, characterized by the fact that it's the "initial X-acyclic" simplicial algebra of M.
The "X-acyclic" structure acts like a deformation retraction from this simplicial algebra to X (which can be thought of as a simplicial algebra as well in a trivial sort of way).
